newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: BOJ's comments leave SIMEX Euroyen, JGBs unmoved.
newsitem.headline: BOJ's comments leave SIMEX Euroyen, JGBs unmoved.

text.p: The Bank of Japan's (BOJ's) slew of comments on Friday left the SIMEX Euroyen and Japanese Government Bond (JGB) futures largely unscathed.
Short-covering and position-squaring ahead of the weekend dominated the day's activity, dealers said.
The dollar's continued rally against the yen, which saw it briefly hit a 47-month high at 120 yen, was said to have little impact, they added.

"The markets were not affected much by BOJ's announcements. Players were mainly pre-occupied with short-covering and squaring their positions ahead of the weekend," said a dealer with a Japanese institution.

Euroyen opened firmer on short-covering following BOJ's announcement on Thursday that it would be postponing the February tankan to early April, triggering speculations that the tankan might be "quite bad", dealers said.
The lead September Euroyen futures traded within a narrow three-tick range, dealers said as players awaited further information from Tokyo.
The September Euroyen contract was trading around 99.33 in late trade against its previous IMM close at 99.30.
It was expected to maintain a firm note next week and trade within 99.25-99.36. A break above 99.36 could prompt upside towards 99.40, dealers said.
JGBs rose on BOJ's concerns about the impact of falling Japanese stock prices on corporate sentiment.
March JGBs tested 126.25 but ended at 126.17 on 279 lots. Its near-term support and resistance were seen at 126.10 and 126.40 respectively.

Eurodollars saw keen local buying in the morning. Activity on the futures only picked up in the afternoon, fuelled by eagerness to short-cover ahead of the weekend. The futures were trapped in narrow range trade after London opened.
September Eurodollars ended unchanged from their IMM close at 93.99 on volume of 11,000 lots.
Dealers said players would keep a close watch on the U.S. fourth quarter Employment Cost Index (ECI), due next Tuesday, for an indication of potential wage pressures.
"People will watch the ECI like a hawk and that will definitely set the tone," said a trader.
